dt: {bc}eagerness and {d_link|ardent|ardent} interest in pursuit of something {bc}{sx|fervor||}

dt.t: … they took office with an undisguised {wi}zeal{/wi} to do everything differently …

pt: {sc}passion{/sc} {sc}fervor{/sc} {sc}ardor{/sc} {sc}enthusiasm{/sc} {sc}zeal{/sc} mean intense emotion compelling action. {sc}passion{/sc} applies to an emotion that is deeply stirring or ungovernable.
{sc}fervor{/sc} implies a warm and steady emotion.

pt.t: read the poem aloud with great {it}fervor{/it}

pt: {sc}ardor{/sc} suggests warm and excited feeling likely to be fitful or short-lived.

pt.t: the {it}ardor{/it} of their honeymoon soon faded

pt: {sc}enthusiasm{/sc} applies to lively or eager interest in or admiration for a proposal, cause, or activity.
{sc}zeal{/sc} implies energetic and unflagging pursuit of an aim or devotion to a cause.

quotes.t: He showed his anatomical {qword}zeal{/qword} by robbing a wayside gibbet, smuggling the bones back home and reconstructing the skeleton.
In 1248, channelling his piety into crusading {qword}zeal{/qword}, Louis embarked on the Seventh Crusade, against the wishes of the Pope and against the judgement of his counsellors.
… he was uncomfortable with their lavish parties and their collector's {qword}zeal{/qword} for the most expensive, most ostentatious brand names—Rolex and Prada and Farragamo.

et: Middle English {it}zele{/it}, from Late Latin {it}zelus{/it}, from Greek {it}zēlos{/it}
shortdef: eagerness and ardent interest in pursuit of something : fervor

dt.t: He spoke with {it}missionary zeal{/it} about the project.

shortdef: great enthusiasm

quotes.t: He had no cause for self-reproach on the score of neglect, or want of thought, for he had been devoted to her service; and yet a hundred little occasions rose up before him, on which he fancied he might have been more {qword}zealous{/qword}, and more earnest, and wished he had been.

{qword}Zealous{/qword} in his ministerial labours, blameless in his life and habits, he yet did not appear to enjoy that mental serenity, that inward content, which should be the reward of every sincere Christian and practical philanthropist.
Sir Thomas was {qword}zealous{/qword} in the pursuit of recusants, not poachers, and was otherwise an amiable man.
I was {qword}zealous{/qword} in my demands on my sisters for promptness in rehearsals. I was passionate, intolerant of small talk, hungry for knowledge, grabby, bossy, precocious.

{sc}zeal{/sc} implies energetic and unflagging pursuit of an aim or devotion to a cause.

dt: {bc}having or producing an optimal balance usually between two extremes

dt.t: While Davis is willing to buy into companies that are cutting dividends, his real focus is {wi}Goldilocks{/wi} stocks, whose yields are neither too high nor too low.
At the right time he lay on his surfboard looking over his shoulder searching for what he calls a {ldquo}{wi}Goldilocks wave{/wi},{rdquo} one that is just right.
In order to succeed, humanitarian efforts require a {ldquo}{wi}Goldilocks{/wi}{rdquo} solution—just the right mix of force and charity, sympathy and structure, blind will and determined follow-up.

dt: {bc}lying in or being an area of planetary orbit in which temperatures are neither too hot nor too cold to support life

dt.t: The planet is smack in the middle of what astronomers call the {phrase}Goldilocks zone{/phrase}, that hard-to-find place that's not too hot, not too cold, where water, which is essential for life, doesn't freeze or boil.

… with nearly 500 exoplanets under their belts, astronomers still haven't found an Earth-size planet in a star's habitable zone—also known as the {wi}Goldilocks{/wi} region, where things are not too hot, not too cold, but just right for life.

To qualify as {ldquo}Earthlike,{rdquo} a planet must not only fall within a reasonable approximation of Earth's composition, mass, gravity, and spin. It must also be located in what astronomers have dubbed the {ldquo}{wi}Goldilocks{/wi} orbit.{rdquo}

Not all stars of course, are likely to have planets, especially what researchers call {ldquo}{wi}Goldilocks{/wi}{rdquo} planets—not too hot and not too cold for life. And not all life is likely to be intelligent.

et: from the character {it}Goldilocks{/it} in the fairy tale "Goldilocks and the Three Bears," who chooses Baby Bear's chair, porridge, and bed (over Papa and Mama Bear's) because it is "just right"
shortdef: having or producing an optimal balance usually between two extremes; specifically, astronomy : lying in or being an area of planetary orbit in which temperatures are neither too hot nor too cold to support life
